title: Prague
text:
Prague ( ; ; , ; ) is the capital and <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20the%20Czech%20Republic">largest city</a> in the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>, the <a href="Largest%20cities%20of%20the%20European%20Union%20by%20population%20within%20city%20limits">13th largest city</a> in the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and the historical capital of <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a>. Situated on the <a href="Vltava">Vltava</a> river, Prague is home to about 1.3 million people, while its <a href="metropolitan%20area">metropolitan area</a> is estimated to have a population of 2.7 million. The city has a <a href="temperate%20climate">temperate</a> <a href="oceanic%20climate">oceanic climate</a>, with relatively warm summers and chilly winters. 
Prague is a political, cultural, and economic center of central Europe complete with a rich history. Founded during the <a href="Romanesque%20architecture">Romanesque</a> and flourishing by the <a href="Czech%20Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a>, <a href="Czech%20Renaissance%20architecture">Renaissance</a> and <a href="Czech%20Baroque%20architecture">Baroque</a> eras, Prague was the capital of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Kingdom of Bohemia</a> and the main residence of several <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>s, most notably of <a href="Charles%20IV%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles IV</a> (r. 1346–1378).
It was an important city to the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> and its <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a>. The city played major roles in the <a href="Bohemian%20Reformation">Bohemian</a> and the <a href="Protestant%20Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>s, the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a> and in 20th-century history as the capital of <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> between the World Wars and the post-war <a href="Communist%20era%20of%20Czechoslovakia">Communist era</a>.
Prague is home to a number of well-known cultural attractions, many of which survived the violence and destruction of 20th-century Europe. Main attractions include <a href="Prague%20Castle">Prague Castle</a>, <a href="Charles%20Bridge">Charles Bridge</a>, <a href="Old%20Town%20Square%20%28Prague%29">Old Town Square</a> with the <a href="Prague%20astronomical%20clock">Prague astronomical clock</a>, the <a href="Josefov">Jewish Quarter</a>, <a href="Pet%C5%99%C3%ADn">Petřín</a> hill and <a href="Vy%C5%A1ehrad">Vyšehrad</a>. Since 1992, the extensive historic center of Prague has been included in the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> list of <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a>s.
The city has more than ten major museums, along with numerous theaters, galleries, cinemas, and other historical exhibits. An extensive modern public transportation system connects the city. It is home to a wide range of public and private schools, including <a href="Charles%20University">Charles University</a> in Prague, the oldest university in <a href="Central%20Europe">Central Europe</a>.
Prague is classified as an "Alpha-" <a href="global%20city">global city</a> according to <a href="GaWC">GaWC</a> studies. In 2019, the city was ranked as 69th most livable city in the world by Mercer. In the same year, the PICSA Index ranked the city as 13th most livable city in the world. Its rich history makes it a popular tourist destination and as of 2017, the city receives more than 8.5 million international visitors annually. In 2017, Prague was listed as the fifth most visited <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an city after <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, and <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>.
Etymology and names.
The Czech name Praha is derived from an old <a href="Slavic%20languages">Slavic</a> word, "práh", which means "<a href="ford%20%28crossing%29">ford</a>" or "<a href="rapid">rapid</a>", referring to the city's origin at a crossing point of the Vltava river. The same etymology is associated with the <a href="Praga">Praga district</a> of <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>.
Another view to the origin of name is also related to the Czech word "práh" (with the meaning of a <a href="Threshold%20%28door%29">threshold</a>) and a legendary etymology connects the name of the city with princess <a href="Libu%C5%A1e">Libuše</a>, prophetess and a wife of mythical founder of the <a href="P%C5%99emyslid%20dynasty">Přemyslid dynasty</a>. She is said to have ordered the city "to be built where a man hews a threshold of his house". The Czech "práh" might thus be understood to refer to rapids or fords in the river, the edge of which could have acted as a means of fording the river – thus providing a "threshold" to the castle.
Another derivation of the name "Praha" is suggested from "na prazě", the original term for the <a href="shale">shale</a> hillside rock upon which the original castle was built. At that time, the castle was surrounded by forests, covering the nine hills of the future city – the <a href="Old%20Town%2C%20Prague">Old Town</a> on the opposite side of the river, as well as the <a href="Lesser%20Town">Lesser Town</a> beneath the existing castle, appeared only later.
The English spelling of the city's name is borrowed from <a href="French%20language">French</a>. In the 19th and early 20th centuries it was pronounced in English to rhyme with "vague": it was so pronounced by <a href="Lady%20Diana%20Cooper">Lady Diana Cooper</a> (born 1892) on <a href="Desert%20Island%20Discs">Desert Island Discs</a> in 1969, and it is written to rhyme with "vague" in a verse of <a href="https%3A//en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Beleaguered_City">The Beleaguered City</a> by <a href="Henry_Wadsworth_Longfellow">Longfellow</a> (1839) and also in the limerick <a href="https%3A//en.wikisource.org/wiki/There_was_an_Old_Lady_of_Prague">There was an Old Lady of Prague</a> by <a href="Edward%20Lear">Edward Lear</a> (1846). 
Prague is also called the ""City of a Hundred <a href="Spire">Spire</a>s"", based on a count by 19th century mathematician <a href="Bernard%20Bolzano">Bernard Bolzano</a>; today's count is estimated by the Prague Information Service at 500. Nicknames for Prague have also included: the Golden City, the Mother of Cities and the Heart of Europe.
History.
During the thousand years of its existence, Prague grew from a settlement stretching from <a href="Prague%20Castle">Prague Castle</a> in the north to the fort of <a href="Vy%C5%A1ehrad">Vyšehrad</a> in the south, to become the capital of a modern European country.
Early history.
The region was settled as early as the <a href="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age. Jewish chronicler <a href="David%20Gans">David Solomon Ganz</a>, citing <a href="Cyriacus%20Spangenberg">Cyriacus Spangenberg</a>, claimed that the city was founded as Boihaem in c. 1306 BC by an ancient king, Boyya.
Around the fifth and fourth century BC, a <a href="Celts">Celtic</a> tribe appeared in the area, later establishing settlements including an <a href="oppidum">oppidum</a> in Závist, a present-day suburb of Prague, and naming the region of Bohemia, which means "home of the Boii people". In the last century BC, the Celts were slowly driven away by <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic tribes</a> (<a href="Marcomanni">Marcomanni</a>, <a href="Quadi">Quadi</a>, <a href="Lombards">Lombards</a> and possibly the <a href="Suebi">Suebi</a>), leading some to place the seat of the <a href="Marcomanni">Marcomanni</a> king, <a href="Maroboduus">Maroboduus</a>, in southern Prague in the suburb now called Závist. Around the area where present-day Prague stands, the 2nd century map drawn by <a href="Ptolemy">Ptolemaios</a> mentioned a Germanic city called "Casurgis".
In the late 5th century AD, during the great <a href="Migration%20Period">Migration Period</a> following the collapse of the <a href="Western%20Roman%20Empire">Western Roman Empire</a>, the Germanic tribes living in Bohemia moved westwards and, probably in the 6th century, the <a href="West%20Slavs">Slavic tribes</a> (Venedi) settled the Central Bohemian Region. In the following three centuries, the <a href="Czechs">Czech tribes</a> built several fortified settlements in the area, most notably in the <a href="Divok%C3%A1%20%C5%A0%C3%A1rka">Šárka valley</a>, <a href="Jinonice">Butovice</a> and <a href="Lev%C3%BD%20Hradec">Levý Hradec</a>.
The construction of what came to be known as <a href="Prague%20Castle">Prague Castle</a> began near the end of the 9th century, expanding a fortified settlement that had existed on the site since the year 800. The first masonry under Prague Castle dates from the year 885 at the latest. The other prominent Prague fort, the Přemyslid fort <a href="Vy%C5%A1ehrad">Vyšehrad</a>, was founded in the 10th century, some 70 years later than Prague Castle. Prague Castle is dominated by the <a href="St.%20Vitus%20Cathedral">cathedral</a>, which began construction in 1344, but wasn't completed until the 20th century.
The legendary origins of Prague attribute its foundation to the 8th-century Czech duchess and prophetess <a href="Libu%C5%A1e">Libuše</a> and her husband, <a href="P%C5%99emysl%2C%20the%20Ploughman">Přemysl</a>, founder of the <a href="P%C5%99emyslid%20dynasty">Přemyslid dynasty</a>. Legend says that Libuše came out on a rocky cliff high above the Vltava and prophesied: "I see a great city whose glory will touch the stars." She ordered a castle and a town called Praha to be built on the site.
The region became the seat of the <a href="duke">duke</a>s, and later <a href="King%20of%20Bohemia">kings of Bohemia</a>. Under Duke of Bohemia <a href="Boleslaus%20II%2C%20Duke%20of%20Bohemia">Boleslaus II the Pious</a> the area became a <a href="Diocese">bishopric</a> in 973. Until Prague was elevated to <a href="archbishopric">archbishopric</a> in 1344, it was under the jurisdiction of the <a href="Archbishopric%20of%20Mainz">Archbishopric of Mainz</a>.
Prague was an important seat for trading where merchants from across Europe settled, including many Jews, as recalled in 965 by the <a href="Al-Andalus">Hispano-Jewish</a> merchant and traveler <a href="Abraham%20ben%20Jacob">Abraham ben Jacob</a>. The <a href="Old%20New%20Synagogue">Old New Synagogue</a> of 1270 still stands in the city. Prague was also once home to an important <a href="slavery">slave market</a>.
At the site of the ford in the Vltava river, King <a href="Vladislaus%20II%2C%20Duke%20of%20Bohemia">Vladislaus I</a> had the first bridge built in 1170, the Judith Bridge (Juditin most), named in honor of his wife <a href="Judith%20of%20Thuringia">Judith of Thuringia</a>. This bridge was destroyed by a flood in 1342, but some of the original foundation stones of that bridge remain in the river. It was rebuilt and named the Charles Bridge.
In 1257, under King <a href="Ottokar%20II%20of%20Bohemia">Ottokar II</a>, <a href="Mal%C3%A1%20Strana">Malá Strana</a> ("Lesser Quarter") was founded in Prague on the site of an older village in what would become the <a href="Hrad%C4%8Dany">Hradčany</a> (Prague Castle) area. This was the district of the German people, who had the right to administer the law autonomously, pursuant to <a href="Magdeburg%20rights">Magdeburg rights</a>. The new district was on the bank opposite of the <a href="Old%20Town%20%28Prague%29">Staré Město</a> ("Old Town"), which had <a href="borough">borough</a> status and was bordered by a line of walls and fortifications.
Late Middle Ages.
Prague flourished during the 14th-century reign (1346–1378) of <a href="Charles%20IV%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor</a> and the king of <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a> of the new <a href="House%20of%20Luxembourg">Luxembourg dynasty</a>. As King of Bohemia and Holy Roman Emperor, he transformed Prague into an imperial capital and it was at that time by the area the third-largest city in Europe (after Rome and <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>).
Charles IV ordered the building of the <a href="New%20Town%2C%20Prague">New Town</a> (Nové Město) adjacent to the <a href="Old%20Town%20%28Prague%29">Old Town</a> and laid out the design himself. The Charles Bridge, replacing the Judith Bridge destroyed in the flood just prior to his reign, was erected to connect the east bank districts to the Malá Strana and castle area. On 9 July 1357 at 5:31 am, Charles IV personally laid the first foundation stone for the Charles Bridge. The exact time of laying the first foundation stone is known because the <a href="palindromic%20number">palindromic number</a> 135797531 was carved into the Old Town bridge tower having been chosen by the royal astrologists and numerologists as the best time for starting the bridge construction. In 1347, he founded <a href="Charles%20University">Charles University</a>, which remains the <a href="List%20of%20oldest%20universities%20in%20continuous%20operation">oldest university</a> in Central Europe.
He began construction of the <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a> <a href="St.%20Vitus%20Cathedral">Saint Vitus Cathedral</a>, within the largest of the Prague Castle courtyards, on the site of the Romanesque rotunda there. Prague was elevated to an archbishopric in 1344, the year the cathedral was begun.
The city had a <a href="mint%20%28coin%29">mint</a> and was a center of trade for German and Italian bankers and merchants. The social order, however, became more turbulent due to the rising power of the <a href="Artisan">craftsmen</a>'s <a href="guild">guild</a>s (themselves often torn by internal fights), and the increasing number of poor.
The Hunger Wall, a substantial fortification wall south of Malá Strana and the Castle area, was built during a famine in the 1360s. The work is reputed to have been ordered by Charles IV as a means of providing employment and food to the workers and their families.
Charles IV died in 1378. During the reign of his son, King <a href="Wenceslaus%2C%20King%20of%20the%20Romans">Wenceslaus IV</a> (1378–1419), a period of intense turmoil ensued. During Easter 1389, members of the Prague clergy announced that Jews had desecrated the host (Eucharistic wafer) and the clergy encouraged mobs to pillage, ransack and burn the Jewish quarter. Nearly the entire Jewish population of Prague (3,000 people) was murdered.
<a href="Jan%20Hus">Jan Hus</a>, a theologian and <a href="Rector%20%28academia%29">rector</a> at the Charles University, preached in Prague. In 1402, he began giving sermons in the <a href="Bethlehem%20Chapel">Bethlehem Chapel</a>. Inspired by <a href="John%20Wycliffe">John Wycliffe</a>, these sermons focused on what were seen as radical reforms of a corrupt Church. Having become too dangerous for the political and religious establishment, Hus was summoned to the <a href="Council%20of%20Constance">Council of Constance</a>, put on trial for <a href="heresy">heresy</a>, and burned at the stake in <a href="Constanz">Constanz</a> in 1415.
Four years later Prague experienced its <a href="Defenestrations%20of%20Prague">first defenestration</a>, when the people rebelled under the command of the Prague priest <a href="Jan%20%C5%BDelivsk%C3%BD">Jan Želivský</a>. Hus' death, coupled with Czech proto-nationalism and <a href="proto-Protestantism">proto-Protestantism</a>, had spurred the <a href="Hussite%20Wars">Hussite Wars</a>. Peasant rebels, led by the general <a href="Jan%20%C5%BDi%C5%BEka">Jan Žižka</a>, along with Hussite troops from Prague, defeated Emperor <a href="Sigismund%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Sigismund</a>, in the <a href="Battle%20of%20V%C3%ADtkov%20Hill">Battle of Vítkov Hill</a> in 1420.
During the <a href="Hussite%20Wars">Hussite Wars</a> when the City of Prague was attacked by "Crusader" and mercenary forces, the city militia fought bravely under the Prague Banner. This swallow-tailed banner is approximately , with a red field sprinkled with small white fleurs-de-lis, and a silver old Town Coat-of-Arms in the center . The words "PÁN BŮH POMOC NAŠE" (The Lord is our Relief/Help) appeared above the coat-of-arms, with a Hussite chalice centered on the top. Near the swallow-tails is a crescent-shaped golden sun with rays protruding.
One of these banners was captured by Swedish troops in <a href="Battle%20of%20Prague%20%281648%29">Battle of Prague (1648)</a>, when they captured the western bank of the Vltava river and were repulsed from the eastern bank, they placed it in the <a href="Swedish%20Army%20Museum">Royal Military Museum</a> in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>; although this flag still exists, it is in very poor condition. They also took the <a href="Codex%20Gigas">Codex Gigas</a> and the <a href="Codex%20Argenteus">Codex Argenteus</a>. The earliest evidence indicates that a gonfalon with a municipal charge painted on it was used for Old Town as early as 1419. Since this city militia flag was in use before 1477 and during the Hussite Wars, it is the oldest still preserved municipal flag of Bohemia.
In the following two centuries, Prague strengthened its role as a merchant city. Many noteworthy Gothic buildings were erected and <a href="Vladislav%20Hall">Vladislav Hall</a> of the Prague Castle was added.
Habsburg era.
In 1526, the Bohemian estates elected <a href="Ferdinand%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Ferdinand I</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a>. The fervent Catholicism of its members brought them into conflict in Bohemia, and then in Prague, where Protestant ideas were gaining popularity. These problems were not preeminent under Holy Roman Emperor <a href="Rudolf%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Rudolf II</a>, elected King of Bohemia in 1576, who chose Prague as his home. He lived in the Prague Castle, where his court welcomed not only astrologers and magicians but also scientists, musicians, and artists. Rudolf was an art lover as well, and Prague became the capital of European culture. This was a prosperous period for the city: famous people living there in that age include the astronomers <a href="Tycho%20Brahe">Tycho Brahe</a> and <a href="Johannes%20Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a>, the painter <a href="Giuseppe%20Arcimboldo">Arcimboldo</a>, the alchemists <a href="Edward%20Kelley">Edward Kelley</a> and <a href="John%20Dee">John Dee</a>, the poet <a href="Elizabeth%20Jane%20Weston">Elizabeth Jane Weston</a>, and others.
In 1618, the famous <a href="Defenestrations%20of%20Prague">second defenestration of Prague</a> provoked the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>, a particularly harsh period for Prague and Bohemia. <a href="Ferdinand%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Ferdinand II</a> of Habsburg was deposed, and his place as King of Bohemia taken by <a href="Frederick%20V%2C%20Elector%20Palatine">Frederick V, Elector Palatine</a>; however his army was crushed in the <a href="Battle%20of%20White%20Mountain">Battle of White Mountain</a> (1620) not far from the city. Following this in 1621 was an execution of 27 Czech Protestant leaders (involved in the uprising) in Old Town Square and the exiling of many others. Prague was forcibly converted back to <a href="Roman%20Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> followed by the rest of Czech lands. The city suffered subsequently during the war under an attack by <a href="Electorate%20of%20Saxony">Electorate of Saxony</a> (1631) and during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Prague%20%281648%29">Battle of Prague (1648)</a>. Prague began a steady decline which reduced the population from the 60,000 it had had in the years before the war to 20,000. In the second half of the 17th century, Prague's population began to grow again. <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20the%20Czech%20Republic">Jews</a> had been in Prague since the end of the 10th century and, by 1708, they accounted for about a quarter of Prague's population.
In 1689, a great fire devastated Prague, but this spurred a renovation and a rebuilding of the city. In 1713–14, a major outbreak of <a href="plague%20%28disease%29">plague</a> hit Prague one last time, killing 12,000 to 13,000 people.
In 1744, <a href="Frederick%20the%20Great">Frederick the Great</a> of Prussia invaded Bohemia. He took Prague after a severe and prolonged siege in the course of which a large part of the town was destroyed. In 1757 the <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>n bombardment destroyed more than one quarter of the city and heavily damaged St. Vitus Cathedral. However a month later, Frederick the Great was defeated and forced to retreat from Bohemia.
The economy of Prague continued to improve during the 18th century. The population increased to 80,000 inhabitants by 1771. Many rich merchants and nobles enhanced the city with a host of palaces, churches and gardens full of art and music, creating a <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> city renowned throughout the world to this day.
In 1784, under <a href="Joseph%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Joseph II</a>, the four municipalities of Malá Strana, Nové Město, Staré Město, and Hradčany were merged into a single entity. The Jewish district, called <a href="Josefov">Josefov</a>, was included only in 1850. The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> produced great changes and developments in Prague, as new factories could take advantage of the coal mines and ironworks of the nearby regions. A first suburb, <a href="Karl%C3%ADn">Karlín</a>, was created in 1817, and twenty years later the population exceeded 100,000.
<a href="Revolutions%20of%201848">The revolutions in Europe in 1848</a> also touched Prague, but they were fiercely suppressed. In the following years, the <a href="Czech%20National%20Revival">Czech National Revival</a> began its rise, until it gained the majority in the town council in 1861. Prague had a German-speaking majority in 1848, but by 1880 the number of German speakers had decreased to 14% (42,000), and by 1910 to 6.7% (37,000), due to a massive increase of the city's overall population caused by the influx of <a href="Czechs">Czechs</a> from the rest of Bohemia and <a href="Moravia">Moravia</a> and the increasing prestige and importance of the Czech language as part of the Czech National Revival.
20th century.
First Czechoslovak Republic.
World War I ended with the defeat of the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> and the creation of Czechoslovakia. Prague was chosen as its capital and Prague Castle as the seat of president <a href="Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Garrigue%20Masaryk">Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk</a>. At this time Prague was a true European capital with highly developed industry. By 1930, the population had risen to 850,000.
Second World War.
<a href="Hitler">Hitler</a> ordered the <a href="German%20Army%20%28Wehrmacht%29">German Army</a> to enter Prague on 15 March 1939, and from Prague Castle proclaimed <a href="Protectorate%20of%20Bohemia%20and%20Moravia">Bohemia and Moravia a German protectorate</a>. For most of its history, Prague had been a multi-ethnic city with important Czech, German and (mostly native German-speaking) Jewish populations. From 1939, when the country was occupied by <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, Hitler took over Prague Castle. During the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, most Jews were <a href="Holocaust">deported and killed</a> by the Germans. In 1942, Prague was witness to the assassination of one of the most powerful men in <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>—<a href="Reinhard%20Heydrich">Reinhard Heydrich</a>—during <a href="Operation%20Anthropoid">Operation Anthropoid</a>, accomplished by Czechoslovak national heroes <a href="Jozef%20Gab%C4%8D%C3%ADk">Jozef Gabčík</a> and <a href="Jan%20Kubi%C5%A1">Jan Kubiš</a>. Hitler ordered bloody reprisals.
In February 1945, <a href="1945%20Bombing%20of%20Prague">Prague suffered several bombing raids</a> by the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">US Army Air Forces</a>. 701 people were killed, more than 1,000 people were injured and some buildings, factories and historical landmarks (<a href="Emmaus%20Monastery">Emmaus Monastery</a>, <a href="Faust%20House%20%28Prague%29">Faust House</a>, <a href="Vinohrady%20Synagogue">Vinohrady Synagogue</a>) were destroyed. Many historic structures in Prague, however, escaped the destruction of the war and the damage was small compared to the total destruction of many other cities in that time. According to American pilots, it was the result of a navigational mistake. In March, a deliberate raid targeted military factories in Prague, killing about 370 people.
On 5 May 1945, two days before Germany capitulated, an <a href="Prague%20uprising">uprising</a> against Germany occurred. Several thousand Czechs were killed in four days of bloody street fighting, with many atrocities committed by both sides. At daybreak on 9 May, the of the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> took the city almost unopposed. The majority (about 50,000 people) of the German population of Prague either fled or were <a href="Expulsion%20of%20Germans%20after%20World%20War%20II">expelled</a> by the <a href="Bene%C5%A1%20decrees">Beneš decrees</a> in the aftermath of the war.
Cold War.
Prague was a city in a country under the military, economic, and political control of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> (see <a href="Iron%20Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> and <a href="COMECON">COMECON</a>). The world's largest <a href="Stalin%20Monument%20%28Prague%29">Stalin Monument</a> was unveiled on <a href="Letn%C3%A1">Letná</a> hill in 1955 and destroyed in 1962. 
The 4th Czechoslovak Writers' Congress, held in the city in June 1967, took a strong position against the regime. On 31 October 1967 students demonstrated at <a href="Strahov%20%28district%20of%20Prague%29">Strahov</a>. This spurred the new secretary of the <a href="Czechoslovak%20Communist%20Party">Czechoslovak Communist Party</a>, <a href="Alexander%20Dub%C4%8Dek">Alexander Dubček</a>, to proclaim a new deal in his city's and country's life, starting the short-lived season of the "<a href="socialism%20with%20a%20human%20face">socialism with a human face</a>". It was the <a href="Prague%20Spring">Prague Spring</a>, which aimed at the renovation of political institutions in a democratic way. The other <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> member countries, except <a href="Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20Albania">Albania</a>, were led by the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> to repress these reforms through the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact%20invasion%20of%20Czechoslovakia">invasion of Czechoslovakia</a> and the capital, Prague, on 21 August 1968. The invasion, chiefly by infantry and tanks, effectively suppressed any further attempts at reform. The military occupation of Czechoslovakia by the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> would end only in 1991.
<a href="Jan%20Palach">Jan Palach</a> and <a href="Jan%20Zaj%C3%ADc">Jan Zajíc</a> committed suicide by <a href="self-immolation">self-immolation</a> in January and February 1969 to protest against the "<a href="Normalization%20%28Czechoslovakia%29">normalization</a>" of the country.
After the Velvet Revolution.
In 1989, after the riot police beat back a peaceful student demonstration, the <a href="Velvet%20Revolution">Velvet Revolution</a> crowded the streets of Prague, and the capital of <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> benefited greatly from the new mood. In 1993, after the <a href="Velvet%20Divorce">Velvet Divorce</a>, Prague became the capital city of the new Czech Republic. From 1995 high-rise buildings began to be built in Prague in large quantities. In the late 1990s, Prague again became an important cultural center of Europe and was notably influenced by <a href="globalisation">globalisation</a>. In 2000, <a href="IMF">IMF</a> and <a href="World%20Bank">World Bank</a> summit took place in Prague and <a href="Anti-globalization%20protests%20in%20Prague">anti-globalization riots</a> took place here. In 2002, Prague suffered from <a href="2002%20European%20floods">widespread floods</a> that damaged buildings and its underground transport system.
Prague <a href="Prague%20bid%20for%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics">launched a bid</a> for the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a>, but failed to make the candidate city <a href="shortlist">shortlist</a>. In June 2009, as the result of financial pressures from the global recession, Prague's officials also chose to cancel the city's planned bid for the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a>.
Geography.
Prague is situated on the <a href="Vltava">Vltava</a> river, at . in the center of the Bohemian Basin. Prague is approximately at the same latitude as <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, Germany; <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, France; and <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, Canada.
Climate.
Prague has an <a href="oceanic%20climate">oceanic climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a>: "Cfb") with <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental</a> ("Dfb") influences, defined as such by the isotherm. The winters are relatively cold with average temperatures at about freezing point, and with very little sunshine. Snow cover can be common between mid-November and late March although snow accumulations of more than are infrequent. There are also a few periods of mild temperatures in winter. Summers usually bring plenty of sunshine and the average high temperature of . Nights can be quite cool even in summer, though. Precipitation in Prague (and most of the Bohemian lowland) is rather low (just over per year) since it is located in the <a href="rain%20shadow">rain shadow</a> of the <a href="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> and other mountain ranges. The driest season is usually winter while late spring and summer can bring quite heavy rain, especially in form of thundershowers. <a href="Inversion%20%28meteorology%29">Temperature inversions</a> are relatively common between mid-October and mid-March bringing foggy, cold days and sometimes moderate air pollution. Prague is also a windy city with common sustained western winds and an average wind speed of that often help break temperature inversions and clear the air in cold months. 
Administration.
Administrative division.
Prague is the capital of the Czech Republic and as such is the regular seat of its central authorities. Since 24 November 1990, it is de facto again a statutory town, but has a specific status of the municipality and the region at the same time. Prague also houses the administrative institutions of the <a href="Central%20Bohemian%20Region">Central Bohemian Region</a>.
Until 1949, all administrative districts of Prague were formed by the whole one or more cadastral unit, municipality or town. Since 1949, there has been a fundamental change in the administrative division. Since then, the boundaries of many urban districts, administrative districts and city districts are independent of the boundaries of cadastral territories and some cadastral territories are thus divided into administrative and self-governing parts of the city. <a href="Cadastre">Cadastral area</a> (for example, <a href="Vinohrady">Vinohrady</a>, <a href="Sm%C3%ADchov">Smíchov</a>) are still relevant especially for the registration of land and real estate and house numbering.
Prague is divided into 10 municipal districts (1–10), 22 administrative districts (1–22), 57 municipal parts, or 112 cadastral areas.
City government.
Prague is autonomously administered by the <a href="Prague%20City%20Assembly">Prague City Assembly</a>, which is elected through municipal elections and consists of 55 to 70 members. Executive body of Prague, elected by the Assembly is a <a href="Prague%20City%20Council">Prague City Council</a>. The municipal office of Prague is called <a href="Prague%20City%20Hall">Prague City Hall</a>. It has 11 members including the <a href="List%20of%20mayors%20of%20Prague">mayor</a> and it prepares proposals for the Assembly meetings and ensures that adopted resolutions are fulfilled. The <a href="Mayor%20of%20Prague">Mayor of Prague</a> is <a href="Czech%20Pirate%20Party">Czech Pirate Party</a> member <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20H%C5%99ib">Zdeněk Hřib</a>.
Population.
According to the 2011 census, about 14% of the city inhabitants were born outside the Czech Republic. That is the highest proportion in the country. However, in 2011, 64.8 per cent of the city's population self-identified themselves as <a href="Czechs">Czechs</a>, which is higher than the national average. Even though official population of Prague hovers around 1.3 million, the real number of people in the city is much higher due to only 65% of its residents being marked as permanently living in the city, these data were taken from mobile phone movements around the city, and bring total population of Prague to about 1.9–2 million, and with additional 300,000 to 400,000 people coming to the city for work, education or shopping, on weekdays there are more than 2 million people in the city.

Culture.
The city is traditionally one of the cultural centres of Europe, hosting many cultural events. Some of the significant cultural institutions include the <a href="National%20Theatre%20%28Prague%29">National Theatre</a> ("Národní Divadlo") and the <a href="Estates%20Theatre">Estates Theatre</a> ("Stavovské or Tylovo" or "Nosticovo divadlo"), where the premières of <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Mozart</a>'s "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>" and "<a href="La%20clemenza%20di%20Tito">La clemenza di Tito</a>" were held. Other major cultural institutions are the <a href="Rudolfinum">Rudolfinum</a> which is home to the <a href="Czech%20Philharmonic">Czech Philharmonic Orchestra</a> and the <a href="Municipal%20House">Municipal House</a> which is home to the <a href="Prague%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Prague Symphony Orchestra</a>. The <a href="State%20Opera%20%28Prague%29">Prague State Opera</a> (Státní opera) performs at the Smetana Theatre.
The city has many world-class museums, including the <a href="National%20Museum%20%28Prague%29">National Museum</a> (Národní muzeum), the Museum of the Capital City of Prague, the <a href="Jewish%20Museum%20in%20Prague">Jewish Museum in Prague</a>, the <a href="Alfons%20Mucha">Alfons Mucha</a> Museum, the African-Prague Museum, the <a href="Museum%20of%20Decorative%20Arts%20in%20Prague">Museum of Decorative Arts in Prague</a>, the <a href="N%C3%A1prstek%20Museum">Náprstek Museum</a> (Náprstkovo Muzeum), the <a href="Josef%20Sudek%20Gallery">Josef Sudek Gallery</a> and <a href="The%20Josef%20Sudek%20Studio">The Josef Sudek Studio</a>, the <a href="Clementinum">National Library</a> and the <a href="National%20Gallery%20in%20Prague">National Gallery</a>, which manages the largest collection of art in the Czech Republic.
There are hundreds of concert halls, galleries, cinemas and music clubs in the city. It hosts <a href="List%20of%20festivals">music festivals</a> including the <a href="Prague%20Spring%20International%20Music%20Festival">Prague Spring International Music Festival</a>, the <a href="Prague%20Autumn%20International%20Music%20Festival">Prague Autumn International Music Festival</a>, the <a href="Prague%20International%20Organ%20Festival">Prague International Organ Festival</a>, the Dvořák Prague International Music Festival, and the <a href="Prague%20International%20Jazz%20Festival">Prague International Jazz Festival</a>. Film festivals include the <a href="Febiofest">Febiofest</a>, the <a href="One%20World%20Film%20Festival">One World Film Festival</a> and Echoes of the <a href="Karlovy%20Vary%20International%20Film%20Festival">Karlovy Vary International Film Festival</a>. The city also hosts the <a href="Prague%20Writers%27%20Festival">Prague Writers' Festival</a>, the Prague Folklore Days, Prague Advent Choral Meeting the <a href="Summer%20Shakespeare%20Festival">Summer Shakespeare Festival</a>, the <a href="Prague%20Fringe%20Festival">Prague Fringe Festival</a>, the <a href="World%20Roma%20Festival">World Roma Festival</a>, as well as the hundreds of <a href="Vernissage">Vernissage</a>s and <a href="fashion%20show">fashion show</a>s.
Many films have been made at <a href="Barrandov%20Studios">Barrandov Studios</a> and at Prague Studios. Cuisine.
In 2008, the <a href="Allegro%20%28restaurant%29">Allegro</a> restaurant received the first <a href="Michelin%20Guide">Michelin star</a> in the whole of the post-Communist part of Central Europe. It retained its star until 2011. , there are two Michelin-starred restaurants in Prague: <a href="La%20Degustation">La Degustation</a> Bohême Bourgeoise and Field. Another six have been awarded Michelin's Bib Gourmand: Bistrøt 104, Divinis, Eska, Maso a Kobliha, Na Kopci and Sansho.
In Malá Strana, Staré Město, <a href="%C5%BDi%C5%BEkov">Žižkov</a> and <a href="Nusle">Nusle</a> there are hundreds of restaurants, bars and pubs, especially with Czech beer. Prague also hosts the <a href="Czech%20Beer%20Festival">Czech Beer Festival</a> (Český pivní festival), which is the largest <a href="beer%20festival">beer festival</a> in the Czech Republic held for 17 days every year in May. At the festival, more than 70 brands of Czech beer can be tasted. There are several microbrewery festivals throughout the year as well.
<a href="Czech%20beer">Czech beer</a> has a long history, with brewing taking place in <a href="B%C5%99evnov%20Monastery">Břevnov Monastery</a> in 993. Prague is home to historical <a href="brewery">breweries</a> <a href="Staropramen%20Brewery">Staropramen</a> (Praha 5), <a href="U%20Flek%C5%AF">U Fleků</a>, <a href="U%20Medv%C3%ADdk%C5%AF">U Medvídků</a>, U Tří růží, <a href="Strahov%20Monastery">Strahov Monastery</a> Brewery (Praha 1) and <a href="B%C5%99evnov%20Monastery%20Brewery">Břevnov Monastery</a> Brewery (Praha 6). Among many microbreweries are: Novoměstský, Pražský most u Valšů, Národní, Boršov, Loď pivovar, U Dobřenských, U Dvou koček, U Supa (Praha 1), Pivovarský dům (Praha 2), Sousedský pivovar Bašta (Praha 4), Suchdolský Jeník, Libocký pivovar (Praha 6), Marina (Praha 7), U Bulovky (Praha 8), Beznoska, Kolčavka (Praha 9), Vinohradský pivovar, Zubatý pes, Malešický mikropivovar (Praha 10), Jihoměstský pivovar (Praha 11), Lužiny (Praha 13), Počernický pivovar (Praha 14) and Hostivar (Praha 15).
Economy.
Prague's economy accounts for 25% of the Czech GDP making it the highest performing regional economy of the country. As of 2019, its GDP per capita in <a href="Purchasing%20power%20parity">purchasing power standard</a> is €63,900, making it the <a href="List%20of%20European%20regions%20by%20GDP">third best performing region in the EU</a> at 205 per cent of the EU-27 average in 2019.
Prague employs almost a fifth of the entire Czech workforce, and its wages are significantly above average (≈+20%). In 4Q/2020, during the pandemic, average salaries available in Prague reached CZK 45.944 (≈<a href="EUR">€</a>1,800) per month, an annual increase of 4%, which was nevertheless lower than national increase of 6.5% both in nominal and real terms. (Inflation in the Czech Republic was 3.2% in 4Q/2020.) Since 1990, the city's economic structure has shifted from industrial to service-oriented. Industry is present in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, printing, food processing, manufacture of transport equipment, computer technology, and electrical engineering. In the service sector, financial and commercial services, trade, restaurants, hospitality and public administration are the most significant. <a href="Service%20%28economics%29">Services</a> account for around 80 per cent of employment. There are 800,000 employees in Prague, including 120,000 commuters. The number of (legally registered) foreign residents in Prague has been increasing in spite of the country's economic downturn. As of March 2010, 148,035 foreign workers were reported to be living in the city making up about 18 per cent of the workforce, up from 131,132 in 2008. Approximately one-fifth of all investment in the Czech Republic takes place in the city.
Almost one-half of the national income from tourism is spent in Prague. The city offers approximately 73,000 beds in accommodation facilities, most of which were built after 1990, including almost 51,000 beds in hotels and boarding houses.
From the late 1990s to late 2000s, the city was a common filming location for international productions such as Hollywood and Bollywood motion pictures. A combination of architecture, low costs and the existing motion picture infrastructure have proven attractive to international film production companies.
The modern economy of Prague is largely service and export-based and, in a 2010 survey, the city was named the best city in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) for business.
In 2005, Prague was deemed among the three best cities in Central and Eastern Europe according to "<a href="The%20Economist">The Economist</a>"'s livability rankings. The city was named as a top-tier nexus city for innovation across multiple sectors of the global innovation economy, placing 29th globally out of 289 cities, ahead of <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a> and <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a> for innovation in 2010 in 2thinknow annual analysts <a href="Innovation%20Cities%20Index">Innovation Cities Index</a>.
<a href="Na%20p%C5%99%C3%ADkop%C4%9B">Na příkopě</a> is the most expensive street among all the states of the <a href="Visegr%C3%A1d%20Group">V4</a>. In 2017, with the amount of rent €2,640 (CZK 67,480) per square meter per year, ranked on 22nd place among the most expensive streets in the world. The second most expensive is Pařížská street.
In the Eurostat research, Prague ranked fifth among Europe's 271 regions in terms of gross domestic product per inhabitant, achieving 172 per cent of the EU average. It ranked just above Paris and well above the country as a whole, which achieved 80 per cent of the EU average.

Tourism.
Since <a href="revolutions%20of%201989">the fall of the Iron Curtain</a>, Prague has become one of the world's most popular tourist destinations. Prague <a href="Bombing%20of%20Prague">suffered considerably less</a> damage during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> than some other major cities in the region, allowing most of its historic architecture to stay true to form. It contains one of the world's most pristine and varied collections of architecture, from <a href="Romanesque%20art">Romanesque</a>, to <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a>, <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>, <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a>, <a href="Rococo">Rococo</a>, <a href="Renaissance%20Revival%20architecture">Neo-Renaissance</a>, <a href="Gothic%20Revival%20architecture">Neo-Gothic</a>, <a href="Art%20Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a>, <a href="Cubism">Cubist</a>, <a href="Neoclassicism">Neo-Classical</a> and ultra-modern.
Prague is classified as an "Alpha-" <a href="global%20city">global city</a> according to <a href="GaWC">GaWC</a> studies, comparable to <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, <a href="Manila">Manila</a> and <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> Prague ranked sixth in the <a href="Tripadvisor">Tripadvisor</a> world list of best destinations in 2016. Its rich history makes it a popular tourist destination, and the city receives more than 8.4 million international visitors annually, .

Science, research and hi-tech centres.
The region city of Prague is an important centre of research. It is the seat of 39 out of 54 institutes of the <a href="Academy%20of%20Sciences%20of%20the%20Czech%20Republic">Czech Academy of Sciences</a>, including the largest ones, the Institute of Physics, the Institute of Microbiology and the Institute of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry. It is also a seat of 10 public research institutes, four <a href="business%20incubator">business incubator</a>s and large hospitals performing <a href="research%20and%20development">research and development</a> activities such as the <a href="Motol%20University%20Hospital">Motol University Hospital</a> or <a href="Institute%20for%20Clinical%20and%20Experimental%20Medicine">Institute for Clinical and Experimental Medicine</a>, which was the largest transplant center in <a href="Europe">Europe</a> as of 2019. Universities seated in Prague (see section "Colleges and Universities") also represent important centres of science and research activities.
, there were 13,000 researchers (out of 30,000 in the country, counted in full-time equivalents), representing a 3% share of Prague's economically active population. Gross expenditure on research and development accounted for €901.3 million (41.5% of country's total).
Some well-known multinational companies have established research and development facilities in Prague, among them <a href="Siemens">Siemens</a>, <a href="Honeywell">Honeywell</a>, <a href="Oracle%20Corporation">Oracle</a>, <a href="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> and <a href="Broadcom%20Inc.">Broadcom</a>.
Prague was selected to host administration of the EU satellite navigation system <a href="Galileo%20%28satellite%20navigation%29">Galileo</a>. It started to provide its first services in December 2016 and full completion is expected by 2020.
Transport.
As of 2017, Prague had transport <a href="modal%20share">modal share</a>: 52% of all trips are done in public transport, 24.5% in car, 22.4% on foot, 0.4% on bike and 0.5% by airplane.
Public transportation.
The public transport infrastructure consists of a heavily used <a href="Prague%20Integrated%20Transport">Prague Integrated Transport</a> (PID, "Pražská integrovaná doprava") of <a href="Prague%20Metro">Prague Metro</a> (lines <a href="line%20A%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">A</a>, <a href="line%20B%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">B</a>, and <a href="line%20C%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">C</a> – its length is with 61 stations in total), <a href="Trams%20in%20Prague">Prague tram system</a>, <a href="Buses%20in%20Prague">Prague buses</a>, <a href="Esko%20Prague">commuter S-trains</a>, <a href="funicular">funicular</a>s, and six <a href="Ferry">ferries</a>. Prague has one of the highest rates of public transport usage in the world, with 1.2 billion passenger journeys per year. Prague has about 300 bus lines (numbers 100–960) and 34 regular tram lines (numbers 1–26 and 91–99 ). There are also three funiculars, one on <a href="Pet%C5%99%C3%ADn%20Hill">Petřín Hill</a>, one on <a href="Mr%C3%A1zovka%20Hill">Mrázovka Hill</a> and a third at the <a href="Prague%20Zoo">Zoo in Troja</a>.
<a href="Trams%20in%20Prague">The Prague tram system</a> now operates various types of trams, including the <a href="Tatra%20T3">Tatra T3</a>, newer <a href="Tatra%20KT8D5">Tatra KT8D5</a>, <a href="Tatra%20T6A5">T6A5</a>, <a href="%C5%A0koda%2014%20T">Škoda 14 T</a> (designed by <a href="Porsche%20Design%20Group">Porsche</a>), newer modern <a href="%C5%A0koda%2015%20T">Škoda 15 T</a> and nostalgic tram lines 23 and 41. Around 400 vehicles are the modernized <a href="Tatra%20T3">T3</a> class, which are typically operated coupled together in pairs.
The Prague tram system is the <a href="Tram%20and%20light%20rail%20transit%20systems">twelfth longest</a> in the world (142 km) and its rolling stock consists of 857 individual cars, which is the third largest in the world behind <a href="Trams%20in%20Moscow">Moscow</a> and <a href="Trams%20in%20Budapest">Budapest</a>. The system carries more than 360 million passengers annually, the highest tram patronage in the world after <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a>, on a per capita basis, Prague has the second highest tram patronage after <a href="Z%C3%BCrich">Zürich</a>.
All services (metro, tramways, city buses, funiculars and ferries) have a common ticketing system that operates on a <a href="proof-of-payment">proof-of-payment</a> system. Basic transfer ticket can be bought for a 30/90-minute ride, short-term tourist passes are available for periods of 24 hours or 3 days, longer-term tickets can be bought on the smart ticketing system <a href="L%C3%ADta%C4%8Dka">Lítačka</a> card, for periods of one month, three months or one year.
Services are run by the <a href="Prague%20Public%20Transport%20Company">Prague Public Transport Company</a> (Dopravní podnik hl. m. Prahy, a. s.) and several other companies. Since 2005 the "Regional Organiser of Prague Integrated Transport (ROPID)" has franchised operation of ferries on the <a href="Vltava">Vltava</a> river, which are also a part of the public transport system with common fares. <a href="Taxicab">Taxi</a> services make pick-ups on the streets or operate from regulated taxi stands.
Prague Metro.
The <a href="Rapid%20transit">Metro</a> has three major lines extending throughout the city: <a href="Line%20A%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">A</a> (green), <a href="Line%20B%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">B</a> (yellow) and <a href="Line%20C%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">C</a> (red). A fourth Metro <a href="Line%20D%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">line D</a> is planned, which would connect the city centre to southern parts of the city (as of 2021, the completion is expected in 2028). The Prague Metro system served 589.2 million passengers in 2012, making it the <a href="List%20of%20metro%20systems">fifth busiest metro system in Europe</a> and the most-patronised in the world on a per capita basis. The first section of the Prague metro was put into operation in 1974. It was the stretch between stations <a href="Ka%C4%8Derov">Kačerov</a> and <a href="Florenc%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">Florenc</a> on the current <a href="line%20C%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">line C</a>. The first part of <a href="line%20A%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">Line A</a> was opened in 1978 (<a href="Dejvick%C3%A1">Dejvická</a> – <a href="N%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD%20M%C3%ADru">Náměstí Míru</a>), the first part of <a href="line%20B%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">line B</a> in 1985 (<a href="And%C4%9Bl%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">Anděl</a> – <a href="Florenc%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">Florenc</a>).
In April 2015, construction finished to extend the green line A further into the northwest corner of Prague closer to the airport. A new interchange station for the bus in the direction of the airport is the station <a href="N%C3%A1dra%C5%BE%C3%AD%20Veleslav%C3%ADn%20%28Prague%20Metro%29">Nádraží Veleslavín</a>. The final station of the green line is <a href="Nemocnice%20Motol">Nemocnice Motol</a> (<a href="Motol%20University%20Hospital">Motol Hospital</a>), giving people direct public transportation access to the largest medical facility in the Czech Republic and one of the largest in Europe. A railway connection to the airport is planned.
In operation there are two kinds of units: "<a href="81-71M">81-71M</a>" which is modernized variant of the Soviet <a href="Metrovagonmash%2081-717/81-714">Metrovagonmash 81-71</a> (completely modernized between 1995 and 2003) and new "<a href="Metro%20M1%20%28Prague%29">Metro M1</a>" trains (since 2000), manufactured by consortium consisting of <a href="Siemens">Siemens</a>, <a href="%C4%8CKD%20%28company%29">ČKD Praha</a> and <a href="ADtranz">ADtranz</a>. The minimum interval between two trains is 90 seconds.
The original Soviet vehicles "<a href="Metrovagonmash%20E%C4%8Ds">Ečs</a>" were excluded in 1997, but one vehicle is placed in public transport museum in depot <a href="St%C5%99e%C5%A1ovice">Střešovice</a>. The <a href="N%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD%20M%C3%ADru">Náměstí Míru</a> metro station is the deepest station and is equipped with the longest <a href="escalator">escalator</a> in <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. The <a href="Prague%20metro">Prague metro</a> is generally considered very safe.
Roads.
The main flow of traffic leads through the centre of the city and through inner and outer ring roads (partially in operation).
Rail.
The city forms the hub of the <a href="%C4%8Cesk%C3%A9%20dr%C3%A1hy">Czech railway</a> system, with services to all parts of the country and abroad. The railway system links Prague with major European cities (which can be reached without transfers), including <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Nuremberg">Nurenberg</a> and <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a> (Germany); <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, <a href="Graz">Graz</a> and <a href="Linz">Linz</a> (Austria); <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a> and <a href="Cracow">Cracow</a> (Poland); <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a> and <a href="Ko%C5%A1ice">Košice</a> (Slovakia); <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a> (Hungary); <a href="Z%C3%BCrich">Zürich</a> (Switzerland); <a href="Split%2C%20Croatia">Split</a> and <a href="Rijeka">Rijeka</a> (Croatia, seasonal); <a href="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> (Serbia, seasonal) and <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a> (Russia). Travel times range between 2 hours to Dresden and 28 hours to Moscow.
Prague's main international railway station is <a href="Praha%20hlavn%C3%AD%20n%C3%A1dra%C5%BE%C3%AD">Hlavní nádraží</a>, rail services are also available from other main stations: <a href="Praha%20Masarykovo%20n%C3%A1dra%C5%BE%C3%AD">Masarykovo nádraží</a>, <a href="Praha-Hole%C5%A1ovice%20railway%20station">Holešovice</a> and <a href="Praha-Sm%C3%ADchov%20railway%20station">Smíchov</a>, in addition to suburban stations. Commuter rail services operate under the name <a href="Esko%20Prague">Esko Praha</a>, which is part of <a href="Prague%20Integrated%20Transport">PID</a> (Prague Integrated Transport).
Air.
Prague is served by <a href="V%C3%A1clav%20Havel%20Airport%20Prague">Václav Havel Airport Prague</a>, the largest airport in the Czech Republic and one of the largest and busiest airports in central and eastern <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. The airport is the hub of carriers <a href="Smartwings">Smartwings</a> and <a href="Czech%20Airlines">Czech Airlines</a> operating throughout Europe. Other airports in Prague include the city's <a href="Prague%E2%80%93Kbely%20Airport">original airport</a> in the north-eastern district of <a href="Prague%2019">Kbely</a>, which is serviced by the <a href="Czech%20Air%20Force">Czech Air Force</a>, also internationally. It also houses the <a href="Prague%20Aviation%20Museum%2C%20Kbely">Prague Aviation Museum</a>. The nearby <a href="Let%C5%88any%20Airport">Letňany Airport</a> is mainly used for private aviation and aeroclub aviation. Another <a href="Vodochody%20Airport">airport</a> in the proximity is <a href="Aero%20Vodochody">Aero Vodochody</a> aircraft factory to the north, used for testing purposes, as well as for aeroclub aviation. There are a few aeroclubs around Prague, such as the <a href="To%C4%8Dn%C3%A1%20Airport">Točná airfield</a>.
Cycling.
In 2018, 1–2.5 % of people commute by <a href="Cycling%20in%20Prague">bike in Prague</a>, depending on season. Cycling is very common as a sport or recreation. As of 2019, there were of protected cycle paths and routes. Also, there were of <a href="bike%20lane">bike lane</a>s and of specially marked bus lanes that are free to be used by cyclists. As of 2021, there are four companies <a href="Bicycle-sharing%20system">providing bicycle sharing</a> in Prague, none of them is subsidized by the city: <a href="Rekola">Rekola</a> (1,000 bikes), <a href="Nextbike">Nextbike</a> (1,000 bikes), <a href="Bolt%20%28company%29">Bolt</a> and <a href="Lime%20%28transportation%20company%29">Lime</a>.
Sport.
Prague is the site of many sports events, national stadiums and teams.
International relations.
The city of Prague maintains its own EU delegation in <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a> called Prague House.
Prague was the location of <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. President</a> <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a>'s speech on 5 April 2009, which led to the <a href="New%20START">New START</a> treaty with Russia, signed in Prague on 8 April 2010.
The annual conference <a href="Forum%202000">Forum 2000</a>, which was founded by former Czech President <a href="V%C3%A1clav%20Havel">Václav Havel</a>, Japanese philanthropist <a href="Y%C5%8Dhei%20Sasakawa">Yōhei Sasakawa</a>, and Nobel Peace Prize laureate <a href="Elie%20Wiesel">Elie Wiesel</a> in 1996, is held in Prague. Its main objective is "to identify the key issues facing civilization and to explore ways to prevent the escalation of conflicts that have religion, culture or ethnicity as their primary components", and also intends to promote democracy in non-democratic countries and to support civil society. Conferences have attracted a number of prominent thinkers, Nobel laureates, former and acting politicians, business leaders and other individuals like: <a href="F.%20W.%20de%20Klerk">Frederik Willem de Klerk</a>, <a href="Bill%20Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>, <a href="Nicholas%20Winton">Nicholas Winton</a>, <a href="Oscar%20Arias%20S%C3%A1nchez">Oscar Arias Sánchez</a>, <a href="Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a>, <a href="Hans%20K%C3%BCng">Hans Küng</a>, <a href="Shimon%20Peres">Shimon Peres</a> and <a href="Madeleine%20Albright">Madeleine Albright</a>.

Namesakes.
A number of other settlements are derived or similar to the name of Prague. In many of these cases, Czech emigration has left a number of namesake cities scattered over the globe, with a notable concentration in the <a href="New%20World">New World</a>.
Additionally, <a href="K%C5%82odzko">Kłodzko</a> is sometimes referred to as "Little Prague" (). Although now in <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, it had been traditionally a part of <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a> until 1763 when it became part of <a href="Silesia">Silesia</a>.
